mainmatter.p: A polynomial p \in \mathcal {P}(R) is said to have degree n if there exists coefficients a_0, a_1, \ldots , a_n \in R and a_n \neq 0 such that p(x) = a_0 + a_1 x + a_2 x^2 + \cdots + a_n x^n for all x \in R. We denote the degree of p by \deg (p) = n. For the zero polynomial, we define its degree to be - \infty.

A function f: R \to R is a polynomial with coefficients in ring R if there exists n \in \N and a_0, a_1, \ldots , a_n \in R such that f(x) = a_0 + a_1 x + a_2 x^2 + \cdots + a_n x^n for all x \in R. We denote the set all polynomials with coefficients in R by \mathcal {P}(R).
